introduction.p: When we gave the formal definition of \int_a^b f(x) \dee{x} in Definition we explained that the integral could be interpreted as the signed area between the curve y=f(x) and the x-axis on the interval [a,b]. In order for this interpretation to make sense we required that a \lt b, and though we remarked that the integral makes sense when a \gt b we did not explain any further. Thankfully there is an easy way to express the integral \int_a^b f(x)\dee{x} in terms of \int_b^a f(x)\dee{x} making it always possible to write an integral so the lower limit of integration is less than the upper limit of integration. Theorem, below, tell us that, for example, \int_7^3 e^x\dee{x} = - \int_3^7 e^x\dee{x}. The same theorem also provides us with two other simple manipulations of the limits of integration.

theorem.title: Arithmetic for the Domain of Integration

ul.li: (left) When 0 \lt a \lt b, the integral represents the area in green which is the difference of two right-angle triangles the larger with area b^2/2 and the smaller with area a^2/2.

(centre) When a \lt 0 \lt b, the integral represents the signed area of the two displayed triangles. The one above the axis has area b^2/2 while the one below has area -a^2/2 (since it is below the axis).
(right) When a \lt b \lt 0, the integral represents the signed area in purple of the difference between the two triangles the larger with area -a^2/2 and the smaller with area -b^2/2.

subsection.title: More properties of integration: even and odd functions
subsection.p:
Recall
We haven't done this in this course, but you should have seen it in your differential calculus course or perhaps even earlier.
the following definition

statement.p:
Let f(x) be a function. Then,
we say that f(x) is even when f(x)=f(-x) for all x, and
we say that f(x) is odd when f(x)=-f(-x) for all x.

subsection.p: Of course most functions are neither even nor odd, but many of the standard functions you know are.

ul.li: Three examples of even functions are f(x)=|x|, f(x)=\cos x and f(x)=x^2. In fact, if f(x) is any even power of x, then f(x) is an even function.

li.p: The part of the graph y=f(x) with x\le 0, may be constructed by drawing the part of the graph with x\ge 0 (as in the figure on the left below) and then reflecting it in the y-axis (as in the figure on the right below).

ul.li: Three examples of odd functions are f(x)=\sin x, f(x)=\tan x and f(x)=x^3. In fact, if f(x) is any odd power of x, then f(x) is an odd function.

li.p: The part of the graph y=f(x) with x\le 0, may be constructed by drawing the part of the graph with x\ge 0 (like the solid line in the figure on the left below) and then reflecting it in the y-axis (like the dashed line in the figure on the left below) and then reflecting the result in the x-axis (i.e. flipping it upside down, like in the figure on the right, below).

statement.p:
Let a \gt 0.
If f(x) is an even function, then
\int_{-a}^a f(x) \dee{x} = 2\int_0^a f(x) \dee{x}
If f(x) is an odd function, then
\int_{-a}^a f(x) \dee{x} = 0

subsection.title: Optional More properties of integration: inequalities for integrals
subsection.p: We are still unable to integrate many functions, however with a little work we can infer bounds on integrals from bounds on their integrands.

statement.p:
Let a\le b be real numbers and let the functions f(x) and g(x) be integrable on the interval a\le x\le b.
If f(x)\ge 0 for all a\le x\le b, then
\int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x} \ge 0
If f(x)\le g(x) for all a\le x\le b, then
\int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x} \le \int_a^b g(x)\,\dee{x}
If there are constants m and M such that m\le f(x)\le M for all a\le x\le b, then
m(b-a)\le \int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x} \le M(b-a)
We have
\bigg|\int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x}\bigg|\le \int_a^b |f(x)|\,\dee{x}

ol.label: a
ol.li: By interpreting the integral as the signed area, this statement simply says that if the curve y=f(x) lies above the x-axis and a\le b, then the signed area of \big\{\ (x,y)\ \big|\ a\le x\le b,\ 0\le y\le f(x)\ \big\} is at least zero. This is quite clear. Alternatively, we could argue more algebraically from Definition. We observe that when we define \int_a^b f(x)\dee{x} via Riemann sums, every summand, f(x_{i,n}^*)\,\frac{b-a}{n}\ge 0. Thus the whole sum is nonnegative and consequently, so is the limit, and thus so is the integral.

Applying part (b) with g(x)=M for all a\le x\le b gives
\int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x} \le \int_a^b M\,\dee{x} = M(b-a)
Similarly, viewing m as a (constant) function, and applying part (b) gives
m\le f(x) \implies \overbrace{\int_a^bm\,\dee{x}}^{=m(b-a)} \le \int_a^b f(x)\,\dee{x}

For any x, |f(x)| is either f(x) or -f(x) (depending on whether f(x) is positive or negative), so we certainly have
f(x)&\le |f(x)| & \text{and}&& -f(x)&\le |f(x)|
Applying part (c) to each of those inequalities gives
\int_a^b f(x)\dee{x} &\le \int_a^b |f(x)|\dee{x} & \text{and} && -\int_a^b f(x)\dee{x} &\le \int_a^b |f(x)|\dee{x}
Now \Big|\int_a^b f(x)\dee{x}\Big| is either equal to \int_a^b f(x)\dee{x} or -\int_a^b f(x)\dee{x} (depending on whether the integral is positive or negative). In either case we can apply the above two inequalities to get the same result, namely
\left|\int_a^b f(x)\dee{x}\right| &\leq \int_a^b |f(x)|\dee{x}.

example.p:
Consider the integral
\int_0^{\frac{\pi}{3}}\sqrt{\cos x}\dee{x}
This is not so easy to compute exactly
It is not too hard to use Riemann sums and a computer to evaluate it numerically: 0.948025319\dots. , but we can bound it quite quickly.

For x between 0 and \frac{\pi}{3}, the function \cos x takes values
You know the graphs of sine and cosine, so you should be able to work this out without too much difficulty.
between 1 and \frac{1}{2}. Thus the function \sqrt{\cos x} takes values between 1 and \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}. That is
\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} &\le \sqrt{\cos x} \le 1 & \text{for $0\le x\le \frac{\pi}{3}$}.
Consequently, by Theorem (b) with a=0, b=\frac{\pi}{3}, m= \frac{1}{\sqrt{2}} and M=1,
\frac{\pi}{3\sqrt{2}} &\le \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \sqrt{\cos x}\dee{x} \le \frac{\pi}{3}
Plugging these expressions into a calculator gives us 0.7404804898 & \le \int_0^{\frac{\pi}{3}} \sqrt{\cos x}\dee{x} \leq 1.047197551
